results.title: Dusty (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Dusty is a film that will captivate with its values of love, loyalty and the quest for freedom. Based on the classic Australian book by Frank Dalby Davison, this is the story of an ill-fated bond between an old man and his dog. Tom Lincoln, an ageing drover, buys Dusty in a hotel, unaware that the dog is part kelpie and part dingo. He trains Dusty into a champion sheep dog but becomes aware his dog has the killer in his blood. Finally he returns to the bush, set apart from the world by his love for his dog. Rated: G

results.title: Dustbins in the sky
results.creator_credit: London Television Service, Bob Thorpe and Mike Lockey
results.brief_description: Made for the television program “Perspective”, this documentary examined the growth of technology in the collection, transmission and dissemination of news, from early cinema newsreels to today’s satellite coverage.

results.title: Dust to dust (A)
results.brief_description: This documentary narrated by Kerry Dwyer reveals how the use by the local council of asbestos tailings from the mine at Baryulgil in New South Wales, which operated until 1977, has affected the health of the predominantly Aboriginal population. The dust was used to maintain roads and keep the earth dust down around the houses. The school itself was built on the tailings. The film records what happened historically at Baryugil and follows the people’s attempts to gain workers’ compensation from the Dust Diseases Board.

results.title: Dust to dust
results.brief_description: Tells the story of a small town in northern NSW and the effects of asbestos mining there. The people estimate that three-quarters of the workers have died or are sick from exposure to asbestos. In presenting their story the film raises issues regarding occupational health in general.

results.title: Durga puja in Calcutta
results.creator_credit: Calcutta Film Society and Mriganka Sekhar Ray
results.brief_description: The monsoon is over…in Bengal it is time for the festival of Durga Puja, goddess of war, militant aspect of Parvati, consort of Shiva. Celebrations praise Durga’s victory over the buffalo demon Mahisasura symbolising triumph of good over evil. The film is an impressionistic view of this festival.

results.title: Durer and the renaissance
results.brief_description: Part of the Art History series, describes the life and work of Albrecht Durer, German painter and engraver, and his part in connecting the artistic development in Italy with that of northern Europe.

results.title: Duran Duran
results.creator_credit: Educational Media International and Russell Mulcahy
results.brief_description: A collection of Duran Duran first eleven videotapes. Two of the clips “Girls on film” and “Chauffeur” contain material which would have a theatrical “M” rating. Adult preview recommended.

results.title: Duplex
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, David Price and Michaela French
results.brief_description: Two elderly neighbours Elsie (Esme Melville) and Dora (Margaret Ricketts) are isolated by the limitations that their old age brings. Both are lonely but fail to strike up a friendship as personal obstacles like pride get in the way. Slowly, slowly, Elsie’s determination breaks Dora’s stubborn resistance and the two begin anew as friends. Written, directed and edited by Michaela French.

results.title: Duntroon: the Royal Military College of Australia [Long version]
results.brief_description: An account of the training of cadet officers at Australia’s military college. In the academic field, there are three courses open - general science, engineering, and arts. Life at the College is shown, including facilities for recreation; rooms for chess and music enthusiasts; clubs, a dance band and an amateur radio station. Duntroon has become famous for its parade ground efficiency and its traditions of loyalty, efficiency and responsibility. Narrated by Keith Eden, photography by Arthur Brown.
